mechanistic interpretability

and reverse engineering neural networks.

  • 29 oct. 2024
  • llms.txt
  • interp

whirlwind tour , initial exploration , glossary

The subfield of alignment that delves into reverse engineering of a neural network, especially LLMs

To attack the curse of dimensionality , the question remains: how do we hope to understand a function over such a large space, without an exponential amount of time? 1

inference

application in the wild: Goodfire and Transluce

How we would do inference with SAE?

idea: treat SAEs as a logit_processor , similar to guided decoding

Current known bottleneck in vLLM:

  • logit_processor are row-wise, or logits are processed synchronously and blocking 2
  • no SPMD currently implemented

steering

refers to the process of manually modifying certain activations and hidden state of the neural net to influence its outputs

For example, the following is a toy example of how a decoder-only transformers (i.e: GPT-2) generate text given the prompt ‚ÄúThe weather in California is‚Äù 

flowchart LR
  A[The weather in California is] --> B[H0] --> D[H1] --> E[H2] --> C[... hot]

To steer to model, we modify H 2 H_2 H 2 ‚Äã layers with certain features amplifier with scale 20 (called it H 3 H_{3} H 3 ‚Äã ) 3 

flowchart LR
  A[The weather in California is] --> B[H0] --> D[H1] --> E[H3] --> C[... cold]

One usually use techniques such as sparse autoencoders to decompose model activations into a set of interpretable features.

For feature ablation , we observe that manipulation of features activation can be strengthened or weakened to directly influence the model‚Äôs outputs

A few examples where ( Panickssery et al., 2024 ) uses contrastive activation additions to steer Llama 2

contrastive activation additions

intuition: using a contrast pair for steering vector additions at certain activations layers

Uses mean difference which produce difference vector similar to PCA:

Given a dataset D \mathcal{D} D of prompt p p p with positive completion c p c_p c p ‚Äã and negative completion c n c_n c n ‚Äã , we calculate mean-difference v MD v_\text{MD} v MD ‚Äã at layer L L L as follow:

v MD = 1 ‚à£ D ‚à£ ‚àë p , c p , c n ‚àà D a L ( p , c p ) ‚àí a L ( p , c n ) v_\text{MD} = \frac{1}{\mid \mathcal{D} \mid} \sum_{p,c_p,c_n \in \mathcal{D}} a_L(p,c_p) - a_L(p, c_n) v MD ‚Äã = ‚à£ D ‚à£ 1 ‚Äã p , c p ‚Äã , c n ‚Äã ‚àà D ‚àë ‚Äã a L ‚Äã ( p , c p ‚Äã ) ‚àí a L ‚Äã ( p , c n ‚Äã )

implication

by steering existing learned representations of behaviors, CAA results in better out-of-distribution generalization than basic supervised finetuning of the entire model.

sparse autoencoders

abbrev: SAE

see also: landspace

Often contains one layers of MLP with few linear ReLU that is trained on a subset of datasets the main LLMs is trained on.

empirical example: if we wish to interpret all features related to the author Camus, we might want to train an SAEs based on all given text of Camus to interpret ‚Äúsimilar‚Äù features from Llama-3.1

definition

We wish to decompose a models‚Äô activitation x ‚àà R n x \in \mathbb{R}^n x ‚àà R n into sparse, linear combination of feature directions:

x ‚àº x 0 + ‚àë i = 1 M f i ( x ) d i ‚àµ d i M ‚â´ n : ¬†latent¬†unit-norm¬†feature¬†direction f i ( x ) ‚â• 0 : ¬†corresponding¬†feature¬†activation¬†for x \begin{aligned} x \sim x_{0} + &\sum_{i=1}^{M} f_i(x) d_i \\[8pt] \because \quad &d_i M \gg n:\text{ latent unit-norm feature direction} \\ &f_i(x) \ge 0: \text{ corresponding feature activation for }x \end{aligned} x ‚àº x 0 ‚Äã + ‚àµ ‚Äã i = 1 ‚àë M ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x ) d i ‚Äã d i ‚Äã M ‚â´ n : ¬†latent¬†unit-norm¬†feature¬†direction f i ‚Äã ( x ) ‚â• 0 : ¬†corresponding¬†feature¬†activation¬†for x ‚Äã

Thus, the baseline architecture of SAEs is a linear autoencoder with L1 penalty on the activations:

training it to reconstruct a large dataset of model activations x ‚àº D x \sim \mathcal{D} x ‚àº D , constraining hidden representation f f f to be sparse

intuition

We need to reconstruction fidelity at a given sparsity level, as measured by L0 via a mixture of reconstruction fidelity and L1 regularization.

We can reduce sparsity loss term without affecting reconstruction by scaling up norm of decoder weights, or constraining norms of columns W dec W_\text{dec} W dec ‚Äã during training

Ideas: output of decoder f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) has two roles

  • detects what features acre active ‚áê L1 is crucial to ensure sparsity in decomposition
  • estimates magnitudes of active features ‚áê L1 is unwanted bias

Gated SAE

uses Pareto improvement over training to reduce L1 penalty ( Rajamanoharan et al., 2024 )

Clear consequence of the bias during training is shrinkage ( Sharkey, 2024 ) 4

Idea is to use gated ReLU encoder ( Dauphin et al., 2017 ; Shazeer, 2020 ) :

feature suppression

See also: link

Loss function of SAEs combines a MSE reconstruction loss with sparsity term:

L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) = ‚à• y ‚àí x ‚à• 2 / d + c ‚à£ f ( x ) ‚à£ ‚àµ d : ¬†dimensionality¬†of x \begin{aligned} L(x, f(x), y) &= \|y-x\|^2/d + c\mid f(x) \mid \\[8pt] &\because d: \text{ dimensionality of }x \end{aligned} L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) ‚Äã = ‚à• y ‚àí x ‚à• 2 / d + c ‚à£ f ( x ) ‚à£ ‚àµ d : ¬†dimensionality¬†of x ‚Äã

the reconstruction is not perfect, given that only one is reconstruction. For smaller value of f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) , features will be suppressed

illustrated example

However, if we train SAE optimizing loss function L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) L(x, f(x), y) L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) , let say encoder outputs feature activation a a a if x = 1 x=1 x = 1 and 0 otherwise, ignore bias term, the optimization problem becomes:

How do we fix feature suppression in training SAEs?

sparse crosscoders

maturity

a research preview from Anthroppic and this is pretty much still a work in progress

see also reproduction on Gemma 2B and github

A variant of sparse autoencoder where it reads and writes to multiple layers ( Lindsey et al., 2024 )

Crosscoders produces shared features across layers and even models

motivations

Resolve:

  • cross-layer features: resolve cross-layer superposition

  • circuit simplification: remove redundant features from analysis and enable jumping across training many uninteresting identity circuit connections

  • model diffing: produce shared sets of features across models. This also introduce one model across training, and also completely independent models with different architectures.

cross-layer superposition

given the additive properties of transformers‚Äô residual stream, adjacent layers in larger transformers can be thought as ‚Äúalmost parallel‚Äù

intuition

In basis of superposition hypothesis, a feature is a linear combinations of neurons at any given layers.

if we think of adjacent layers as being ‚Äúalmost parallel branches that potentially have superposition between them‚Äù, then we can apply dictionary learning jointly 5

persistent features and complexity

Current drawbacks of sparse autoencoders is that we have to train it against certain activations layers to extract features. In terms of the residual stream per layers, we end up having lots of duplicate features across layers.

Crosscoders can simplify the circuit given that we use an appropriate architecture 6

setup.

Autoencoders and transcoders as special cases of crosscoders.

  • autoencoders: reads and predict the same layers
  • transcoders: read from layer n n n and predict layer n + 1 n+1 n + 1

Crosscoder read/write to many layers, subject to causality constraints.

crosscoders

Let one compute the vector of feature activation f ( x j ) f_(x_j) f ( ‚Äã x j ‚Äã ) on data point x j x_j x j ‚Äã by summing over contributions of activations of different layers a l ( x j ) a^l(x_j) a l ( x j ‚Äã ) for layers l ‚àà L l \in L l ‚àà L :

f ( x j ) = ReLU ( ‚àë l ‚àà L W enc l a l ( x j ) + b enc ) ‚àµ W enc l : ¬†encoder¬†weights¬†at¬†layer l ‚àµ a l ( x j ) : ¬†activation¬†on¬†datapoint x j ¬†at¬†layer l \begin{aligned} f(x_j) &= \text{ReLU}(\sum_{l\in L}W_{\text{enc}}^l a^l(x_j) + b_{\text{enc}}) \\[8pt] &\because W^l_{\text{enc}} : \text{ encoder weights at layer } l \\[8pt] &\because a^l(x_j) : \text{ activation on datapoint } x_j \text{ at layer } l \\ \end{aligned} f ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚Äã = ReLU ( l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã W enc l ‚Äã a l ( x j ‚Äã ) + b enc ‚Äã ) ‚àµ W enc l ‚Äã : ¬†encoder¬†weights¬†at¬†layer l ‚àµ a l ( x j ‚Äã ) : ¬†activation¬†on¬†datapoint x j ‚Äã ¬†at¬†layer l ‚Äã

We have loss

L = ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• a l ( x j ) ‚àí a l ‚Ä≤ ( x j ) ‚à• 2 + ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚àë i f i ( x j ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• L = \sum_{l\in L} \|a^l(x_j) - a^{l^{'}}(x_j)\|^2 + \sum_{l\in L}\sum_i f_i(x_j) \|W^l_{\text{dec,i}}\| L = l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã ‚à• a l ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚àí a l ‚Ä≤ ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚à• 2 + l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã i ‚àë ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à•

and regularization can be rewritten as:

‚àë l ‚àà L ‚àë i f i ( x j ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• = ‚àë i f i ( x j ) ( ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• ) \sum_{l\in L}\sum_{i} f_i(x_j) \|W^l_{\text{dec,i}}\| = \sum_{i} f_i(x_j)(\displaystyle\sum_{l \in L} \|W^l_\text{dec,i}\|) l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã i ‚àë ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à• = i ‚àë ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x j ‚Äã ) ( l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à• )

weight of L1 regularization penalty by L1 norm of per-layer decoder weight norms ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• \sum\limits{l\in L} \|W^l_\text{dec,i}\| ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à• 7

We use L1 due to

  • baseline loss comparison: L2 exhibits lower loss than sum of per-layer SAE losses, as they would effectively obtain a loss ‚Äúbonus‚Äù by spreading features across layers

  • layer-wise sparsity surfaces layer-specific features : based on empirical results of model diffing , that L1 uncovers a mix of shared and model-specific features, whereas L2 tends to uncover only shared features.

variants

good to explore:

  1. strictly causal crosscoders to capture MLP computation and treat computation performed by attention layers as linear
  2. combine strictly causal crosscoders for MLP outputs without weakly causal crosscoders for attention outputs
  3. interpretable attention replacement layers that could be used in combination with strictly causal crosscoders for a ‚Äúreplacement model‚Äù

model diffing

see also: model stiching and SVCCA

( Laakso & Cottrell, 2000 ) proposes compare representations by transforming into representations of distances between data points. 8

questions

How do features change over model training? When do they form?

As we make a model wider, do we get more features? or they are largely the same, packed less densely?

Lien vers l'original

superposition hypothesis

tl/dr

phenomena when a neural network represents more than n n n features in a n n n -dimensional space

Linear representation of neurons can represent more features than dimensions. As sparsity increases, model use superposition to represent more features than dimensions.

neural networks ‚Äúwant to represent more features than they have neurons‚Äù.

When features are sparsed, superposition allows compression beyond what linear model can do, at a cost of interference that requires non-linear filtering.

reasoning: ‚Äúnoisy simulation‚Äù, where small neural networks exploit feature sparsity and properties of high-dimensional spaces to approximately simulate much larger much sparser neural networks

In a sense, superposition is a form of lossy compression

importance

  • sparsity: how frequently is it in the input?

  • importance: how useful is it for lowering loss?

over-complete basis

reasoning for the set of n n n directions 9

features

A property of an input to the model

When we talk about features ( Elhage et al., 2022, p. see ‚ÄúEmpirical Phenomena‚Äù ) , the theory building around several observed empirical phenomena:

  1. Word Embeddings: have direction which corresponding to semantic properties ( Mikolov et al., 2013 ) . For example:
  2. Latent space: similar vector arithmetics and interpretable directions have also been found in generative adversarial network.

We can define features as properties of inputs which a sufficiently large neural network will reliably dedicate a neuron to represent ( Elhage et al., 2022, p. see ‚ÄúFeatures as Direction‚Äù )

ablation

refers to the process of removing a subset of a model‚Äôs parameters to evaluate its predictions outcome.

idea: deletes one activation of the network to see how performance on a task changes.

  • zero ablation or pruning : Deletion by setting activations to zero
  • mean ablation: Deletion by setting activations to the mean of the dataset
  • random ablation or resampling

residual stream 

flowchart LR
  A[Token] --> B[Embeddings] --> C[x0]
  C[x0] --> E[H] --> D[x1]
  C[x0] --> D
  D --> F[MLP] --> G[x2]
  D --> G[x2]
  G --> I[...] --> J[unembed] --> X[logits]

residual stream x 0 x_{0} x 0 ‚Äã has dimension ( C , E ) \mathit{(C,E)} ( C , E ) where

  • C \mathit{C} C : the number of tokens in context windows and
  • E \mathit{E} E : embedding dimension.

Attention mechanism H \mathit{H} H process given residual stream x 0 x_{0} x 0 ‚Äã as the result is added back to x 1 x_{1} x 1 ‚Äã :

x 1 = H ( x 0 ) + x 0 x_{1} = \mathit{H}{(x_{0})} + x_{0} x 1 ‚Äã = H ( x 0 ‚Äã ) + x 0 ‚Äã

grokking

See also: writeup , code , circuit threads

A phenomena discovered by ( Power et al., 2022 ) where small algorithmic tasks like modular addition will initially memorise training data, but after a long time ti will suddenly learn to generalise to unseen data

empirical claims

related to phase change

mechanistic interpretability

whirlwind tour , initial exploration , glossary

The subfield of alignment that delves into reverse engineering of a neural network, especially LLMs

To attack the curse of dimensionality , the question remains: how do we hope to understand a function over such a large space, without an exponential amount of time? 1

application in the wild: Goodfire and Transluce

  • logit_processor are row-wise, or logits are processed synchronously and blocking 2
  • no SPMD currently implemented

steering

refers to the process of manually modifying certain activations and hidden state of the neural net to influence its outputs

For example, the following is a toy example of how a decoder-only transformers (i.e: GPT-2) generate text given the prompt ‚ÄúThe weather in California is‚Äù 

flowchart LR
  A[The weather in California is] --> B[H0] --> D[H1] --> E[H2] --> C[... hot]

To steer to model, we modify H 2 H_2 H 2 ‚Äã layers with certain features amplifier with scale 20 (called it H 3 H_{3} H 3 ‚Äã ) 3 

flowchart LR
  A[The weather in California is] --> B[H0] --> D[H1] --> E[H3] --> C[... cold]

One usually use techniques such as sparse autoencoders to decompose model activations into a set of interpretable features.

For feature ablation , we observe that manipulation of features activation can be strengthened or weakened to directly influence the model‚Äôs outputs

A few examples where ( Panickssery et al., 2024 ) uses contrastive activation additions to steer Llama 2

contrastive activation additions

intuition: using a contrast pair for steering vector additions at certain activations layers

Uses mean difference which produce difference vector similar to PCA:

Given a dataset D \mathcal{D} D of prompt p p p with positive completion c p c_p c p ‚Äã and negative completion c n c_n c n ‚Äã , we calculate mean-difference v MD v_\text{MD} v MD ‚Äã at layer L L L as follow:

v MD = 1 ‚à£ D ‚à£ ‚àë p , c p , c n ‚àà D a L ( p , c p ) ‚àí a L ( p , c n ) v_\text{MD} = \frac{1}{\mid \mathcal{D} \mid} \sum_{p,c_p,c_n \in \mathcal{D}} a_L(p,c_p) - a_L(p, c_n) v MD ‚Äã = ‚à£ D ‚à£ 1 ‚Äã p , c p ‚Äã , c n ‚Äã ‚àà D ‚àë ‚Äã a L ‚Äã ( p , c p ‚Äã ) ‚àí a L ‚Äã ( p , c n ‚Äã )

implication

by steering existing learned representations of behaviors, CAA results in better out-of-distribution generalization than basic supervised finetuning of the entire model.

sparse autoencoders

abbrev: SAE

see also: landspace

Often contains one layers of MLP with few linear ReLU that is trained on a subset of datasets the main LLMs is trained on.

empirical example: if we wish to interpret all features related to the author Camus, we might want to train an SAEs based on all given text of Camus to interpret ‚Äúsimilar‚Äù features from Llama-3.1

definition

We wish to decompose a models‚Äô activitation x ‚àà R n x \in \mathbb{R}^n x ‚àà R n into sparse, linear combination of feature directions:

x ‚àº x 0 + ‚àë i = 1 M f i ( x ) d i ‚àµ d i M ‚â´ n : ¬†latent¬†unit-norm¬†feature¬†direction f i ( x ) ‚â• 0 : ¬†corresponding¬†feature¬†activation¬†for x \begin{aligned} x \sim x_{0} + &\sum_{i=1}^{M} f_i(x) d_i \\[8pt] \because \quad &d_i M \gg n:\text{ latent unit-norm feature direction} \\ &f_i(x) \ge 0: \text{ corresponding feature activation for }x \end{aligned} x ‚àº x 0 ‚Äã + ‚àµ ‚Äã i = 1 ‚àë M ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x ) d i ‚Äã d i ‚Äã M ‚â´ n : ¬†latent¬†unit-norm¬†feature¬†direction f i ‚Äã ( x ) ‚â• 0 : ¬†corresponding¬†feature¬†activation¬†for x ‚Äã

Thus, the baseline architecture of SAEs is a linear autoencoder with L1 penalty on the activations:

f ( x ) ‚âî ReLU ( W enc ( x ‚àí b dec ) + b enc ) x ^ ( f ) ‚âî W dec f ( x ) + b dec \begin{aligned} f(x) &\coloneqq \text{ReLU}(W_\text{enc}(x - b_\text{dec}) + b_\text{enc}) \\ \hat{x}(f) &\coloneqq W_\text{dec} f(x) + b_\text{dec} \end{aligned} f ( x ) x ^ ( f ) ‚Äã : = ReLU ( W enc ‚Äã ( x ‚àí b dec ‚Äã ) + b enc ‚Äã ) : = W dec ‚Äã f ( x ) + b dec ‚Äã ‚Äã

training it to reconstruct a large dataset of model activations x ‚àº D x \sim \mathcal{D} x ‚àº D , constraining hidden representation f f f to be sparse

L1 norm with coefficient Œª \lambda Œª to construct loss during training:

L ( x ) ‚âî ‚à• x ‚àí x ^ ( f ( x ) ) ‚à• 2 2 + Œª ‚à• f ( x ) ‚à• 1 ‚àµ ‚à• x ‚àí x ^ ( f ( x ) ) ‚à• 2 2 : ¬†reconstruction¬†loss \begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(x) &\coloneqq \| x-\hat{x}(f(x)) \|_2^2 + \lambda \| f(x) \|_1 \\[8pt] &\because \|x-\hat{x}(f(x)) \|_2^2 : \text{ reconstruction loss} \end{aligned} L ( x ) ‚Äã : = ‚à• x ‚àí x ^ ( f ( x )) ‚à• 2 2 ‚Äã + Œª ‚à• f ( x ) ‚à• 1 ‚Äã ‚àµ ‚à• x ‚àí x ^ ( f ( x )) ‚à• 2 2 ‚Äã : ¬†reconstruction¬†loss ‚Äã

intuition

We need to reconstruction fidelity at a given sparsity level, as measured by L0 via a mixture of reconstruction fidelity and L1 regularization.

We can reduce sparsity loss term without affecting reconstruction by scaling up norm of decoder weights, or constraining norms of columns W dec W_\text{dec} W dec ‚Äã during training

Ideas: output of decoder f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) has two roles

  • detects what features acre active ‚áê L1 is crucial to ensure sparsity in decomposition
  • estimates magnitudes of active features ‚áê L1 is unwanted bias

Gated SAE

uses Pareto improvement over training to reduce L1 penalty ( Rajamanoharan et al., 2024 )

Clear consequence of the bias during training is shrinkage ( Sharkey, 2024 ) 4

Idea is to use gated ReLU encoder ( Dauphin et al., 2017 ; Shazeer, 2020 ) :

feature suppression

See also: link

Loss function of SAEs combines a MSE reconstruction loss with sparsity term:

L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) = ‚à• y ‚àí x ‚à• 2 / d + c ‚à£ f ( x ) ‚à£ ‚àµ d : ¬†dimensionality¬†of x \begin{aligned} L(x, f(x), y) &= \|y-x\|^2/d + c\mid f(x) \mid \\[8pt] &\because d: \text{ dimensionality of }x \end{aligned} L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) ‚Äã = ‚à• y ‚àí x ‚à• 2 / d + c ‚à£ f ( x ) ‚à£ ‚àµ d : ¬†dimensionality¬†of x ‚Äã

the reconstruction is not perfect, given that only one is reconstruction. For smaller value of f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) , features will be suppressed

illustrated example

consider one binary feature in one dimension x = 1 x=1 x = 1 with probability p p p and x = 0 x=0 x = 0 otherwise. Ideally, optimal SAE would extract feature activation of f ( x ) ‚àà { 0 , 1 } f(x) \in \{0,1\} f ( x ) ‚àà { 0 , 1 } and have decoder W d = 1 W_d=1 W d ‚Äã = 1

However, if we train SAE optimizing loss function L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) L(x, f(x), y) L ( x , f ( x ) , y ) , let say encoder outputs feature activation a a a if x = 1 x=1 x = 1 and 0 otherwise, ignore bias term, the optimization problem becomes:

How do we fix feature suppression in training SAEs?

introduce element-wise scaling factor per feature in-between encoder and decoder, represented by vector s s s :

sparse crosscoders

maturity

a research preview from Anthroppic and this is pretty much still a work in progress

see also reproduction on Gemma 2B and github

A variant of sparse autoencoder where it reads and writes to multiple layers ( Lindsey et al., 2024 )

Crosscoders produces shared features across layers and even models

motivations

Resolve:

  • cross-layer features: resolve cross-layer superposition

  • circuit simplification: remove redundant features from analysis and enable jumping across training many uninteresting identity circuit connections

  • model diffing: produce shared sets of features across models. This also introduce one model across training, and also completely independent models with different architectures.

cross-layer superposition

given the additive properties of transformers‚Äô residual stream, adjacent layers in larger transformers can be thought as ‚Äúalmost parallel‚Äù

intuition

In basis of superposition hypothesis, a feature is a linear combinations of neurons at any given layers.

if we think of adjacent layers as being ‚Äúalmost parallel branches that potentially have superposition between them‚Äù, then we can apply dictionary learning jointly 5

persistent features and complexity

Current drawbacks of sparse autoencoders is that we have to train it against certain activations layers to extract features. In terms of the residual stream per layers, we end up having lots of duplicate features across layers.

Crosscoders can simplify the circuit given that we use an appropriate architecture 6

setup.

Autoencoders and transcoders as special cases of crosscoders.

  • autoencoders: reads and predict the same layers
  • transcoders: read from layer n n n and predict layer n + 1 n+1 n + 1

Crosscoder read/write to many layers, subject to causality constraints.

crosscoders

Let one compute the vector of feature activation f ( x j ) f_(x_j) f ( ‚Äã x j ‚Äã ) on data point x j x_j x j ‚Äã by summing over contributions of activations of different layers a l ( x j ) a^l(x_j) a l ( x j ‚Äã ) for layers l ‚àà L l \in L l ‚àà L :

f ( x j ) = ReLU ( ‚àë l ‚àà L W enc l a l ( x j ) + b enc ) ‚àµ W enc l : ¬†encoder¬†weights¬†at¬†layer l ‚àµ a l ( x j ) : ¬†activation¬†on¬†datapoint x j ¬†at¬†layer l \begin{aligned} f(x_j) &= \text{ReLU}(\sum_{l\in L}W_{\text{enc}}^l a^l(x_j) + b_{\text{enc}}) \\[8pt] &\because W^l_{\text{enc}} : \text{ encoder weights at layer } l \\[8pt] &\because a^l(x_j) : \text{ activation on datapoint } x_j \text{ at layer } l \\ \end{aligned} f ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚Äã = ReLU ( l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã W enc l ‚Äã a l ( x j ‚Äã ) + b enc ‚Äã ) ‚àµ W enc l ‚Äã : ¬†encoder¬†weights¬†at¬†layer l ‚àµ a l ( x j ‚Äã ) : ¬†activation¬†on¬†datapoint x j ‚Äã ¬†at¬†layer l ‚Äã

We have loss

L = ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• a l ( x j ) ‚àí a l ‚Ä≤ ( x j ) ‚à• 2 + ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚àë i f i ( x j ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• L = \sum_{l\in L} \|a^l(x_j) - a^{l^{'}}(x_j)\|^2 + \sum_{l\in L}\sum_i f_i(x_j) \|W^l_{\text{dec,i}}\| L = l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã ‚à• a l ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚àí a l ‚Ä≤ ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚à• 2 + l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã i ‚àë ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à•

and regularization can be rewritten as:

‚àë l ‚àà L ‚àë i f i ( x j ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• = ‚àë i f i ( x j ) ( ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• ) \sum_{l\in L}\sum_{i} f_i(x_j) \|W^l_{\text{dec,i}}\| = \sum_{i} f_i(x_j)(\displaystyle\sum_{l \in L} \|W^l_\text{dec,i}\|) l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã i ‚àë ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x j ‚Äã ) ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à• = i ‚àë ‚Äã f i ‚Äã ( x j ‚Äã ) ( l ‚àà L ‚àë ‚Äã ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à• )

weight of L1 regularization penalty by L1 norm of per-layer decoder weight norms ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• W dec,i l ‚à• \sum\limits{l\in L} \|W^l_\text{dec,i}\| ‚àë l ‚àà L ‚à• W dec,i l ‚Äã ‚à• 7

We use L1 due to

  • baseline loss comparison: L2 exhibits lower loss than sum of per-layer SAE losses, as they would effectively obtain a loss ‚Äúbonus‚Äù by spreading features across layers

  • layer-wise sparsity surfaces layer-specific features : based on empirical results of model diffing , that L1 uncovers a mix of shared and model-specific features, whereas L2 tends to uncover only shared features.

variants

good to explore:

  1. strictly causal crosscoders to capture MLP computation and treat computation performed by attention layers as linear
  2. combine strictly causal crosscoders for MLP outputs without weakly causal crosscoders for attention outputs
  3. interpretable attention replacement layers that could be used in combination with strictly causal crosscoders for a ‚Äúreplacement model‚Äù

model diffing

see also: model stiching and SVCCA

( Laakso & Cottrell, 2000 ) proposes compare representations by transforming into representations of distances between data points. 8

questions

How do features change over model training? When do they form?

As we make a model wider, do we get more features? or they are largely the same, packed less densely?

superposition hypothesis

tl/dr

phenomena when a neural network represents more than n n n features in a n n n -dimensional space

Linear representation of neurons can represent more features than dimensions. As sparsity increases, model use superposition to represent more features than dimensions.

neural networks ‚Äúwant to represent more features than they have neurons‚Äù.

When features are sparsed, superposition allows compression beyond what linear model can do, at a cost of interference that requires non-linear filtering.

reasoning: ‚Äúnoisy simulation‚Äù, where small neural networks exploit feature sparsity and properties of high-dimensional spaces to approximately simulate much larger much sparser neural networks

In a sense, superposition is a form of lossy compression

importance

  • sparsity: how frequently is it in the input?

  • importance: how useful is it for lowering loss?

over-complete basis

reasoning for the set of n n n directions 9

features

A property of an input to the model

When we talk about features ( Elhage et al., 2022, p. see ‚ÄúEmpirical Phenomena‚Äù ) , the theory building around several observed empirical phenomena:

  1. Word Embeddings: have direction which corresponding to semantic properties ( Mikolov et al., 2013 ) . For example:
  2. Latent space: similar vector arithmetics and interpretable directions have also been found in generative adversarial network.

We can define features as properties of inputs which a sufficiently large neural network will reliably dedicate a neuron to represent ( Elhage et al., 2022, p. see ‚ÄúFeatures as Direction‚Äù )

ablation

refers to the process of removing a subset of a model‚Äôs parameters to evaluate its predictions outcome.

idea: deletes one activation of the network to see how performance on a task changes.

  • zero ablation or pruning : Deletion by setting activations to zero
  • mean ablation: Deletion by setting activations to the mean of the dataset
  • random ablation or resampling

residual stream 

flowchart LR
  A[Token] --> B[Embeddings] --> C[x0]
  C[x0] --> E[H] --> D[x1]
  C[x0] --> D
  D --> F[MLP] --> G[x2]
  D --> G[x2]
  G --> I[...] --> J[unembed] --> X[logits]

residual stream x 0 x_{0} x 0 ‚Äã has dimension ( C , E ) \mathit{(C,E)} ( C , E ) where

  • C \mathit{C} C : the number of tokens in context windows and
  • E \mathit{E} E : embedding dimension.

Attention mechanism H \mathit{H} H process given residual stream x 0 x_{0} x 0 ‚Äã as the result is added back to x 1 x_{1} x 1 ‚Äã :

x 1 = H ( x 0 ) + x 0 x_{1} = \mathit{H}{(x_{0})} + x_{0} x 1 ‚Äã = H ( x 0 ‚Äã ) + x 0 ‚Äã

grokking

See also: writeup , code , circuit threads

A phenomena discovered by ( Power et al., 2022 ) where small algorithmic tasks like modular addition will initially memorise training data, but after a long time ti will suddenly learn to generalise to unseen data

empirical claims

related to phase change
